title: How to Attach and Send Files Over Email (Complete Guide)

steps.title: Click on Compose.
steps.content: Click on Compose . If you haven't opened your email program, do so now.

steps.title: Format your email.
steps.content: Format your email. Enter the email's recipient(s) and subject. You can type out the body of your email, as well. If you want, you can also do this step after you've attached your file(s).

steps.title: Click the button with a paperclip on it.
steps.content: Click the button with a paperclip on it. Depending on your email service, the button might also say Attach or Attachments .

steps.title: Select the file you want to send.
steps.content: Select the file you want to send. To attach the file, navigate to its location, then double-click the file to select it. The Browse window will close and you'll return to your email. If you need to attach multiple files to one email that are in the same folder on your computer, there are a few ways to attach them at the same time: If the files are in order, click the first file, hold down ⇧ Shift , then click the last file. Click Open to attach them. If the files are not in order, hold down Ctrl (Windows) or ⌘ Command (Mac) while clicking each file. Once the last file has been selected, let go of the Ctrl or ⌘ Command key and then click Open . If you want to send the entire folder, Oppido recommends uploading it to Google Drive or Dropbox . Or, if you're composing the email message in Gmail, Oppido suggests dragging the folder directly into the body of the message. "Gmail will offer to upload it to Google Drive and provide a link," he explains. When the recipient receives the link, they can choose which files to download. Most email services will have a limit on how big the files you can attach are. File size is usually limited to a max of 20 to 25 MB. Go to source After you add any attachments, you'll see them listed either at the top or the bottom of the email.

steps.title: Click the Send button.
steps.content: Click the Send button. The email will be sent with your attachments immediately.

steps.title: Open your file in File Explorer or Finder.
steps.content: Open your file in File Explorer or Finder. If you have a file that's too big to attach to an email, you can make it smaller by compressing it. Both Windows and Mac computers have the ability to compress files to make them smaller. If you're sending someone a file that's 3 MB or larger, Oppido recommends uploading the file to Google Drive or Dropbox and sending the recipient a link to the file instead. "I like to be mindful of the person's email space," he explains.

steps.title: Right-click on the file.
steps.content: Right-click on the file. If you're on Mac, you'll need to hold down Ctrl and click. If you're sending multiple large files, add them to a folder, then right-click on the folder. This will save you some time from having to individually compress each file.

steps.title: Compress the file.
steps.content: Compress the file. How you do this differs slightly between Windows and Mac: Windows: Right-click the file and go to Send to… > Compressed (zipped) folder . Mac: Ctrl + click the file and click Compress .

steps.title: Open your email and click on Compose.
steps.content: Open your email and click on Compose . You will now be able to send the compressed file.

steps.title: Format your email.
steps.content: Format your email. Enter the email's recipient(s) and subject. You can type out the body of your email, as well. If you want, you can also do this step after you've attached your file.

steps.title: Click the button with a paperclip on it.
steps.content: Click the button with a paperclip on it. Depending on your email service, the button might also say Attach or Attachments .

steps.title: Navigate to the file you want to send.
steps.content: Navigate to the file you want to send. To attach the file, simply double-click on the file to select it. The Browse window will close and you'll return to your email. If your file is still too large, you can try sending it with Google Drive or Dropbox . There are also websites you can use to send large files. If you are sending the file with Gmail, if the file is too big, Gmail will automatically use Google Drive to send the file. [2] X Research source After you add your attachment, you'll see it listed either at the top or the bottom of the email.

steps.title: Click the Send button.
steps.content: Click the Send button. The email will be sent with your attachment immediately.

steps.title: Go to Google Drive.
steps.content: Go to Google Drive . If you're not already signed in, sign in now.

steps.title: Click New.
steps.content: Click New . It's in the top-left corner of the page.

steps.title: Click File Upload.
steps.content: Click File Upload . If all of the files you want to send are in one folder, you can click Folder Upload instead. Google Drive will zip the folder and upload that file to your Drive.

steps.title: Upload your file(s).
steps.content: Upload your file(s). If you need to upload multiple files that are in the same folder on your computer, there are two ways to select them at the same time: If the files are in order, click the first file, hold down ⇧ Shift , then click the last file. Click Open to attach them. If the files are not in order, hold down Ctrl while clicking each file. Once the last file has been selected, let go of the Ctrl key and then click Open .

steps.title: Get your file link(s).
steps.content: Get your file link(s). For each file you want to send in an email, right-click in Google Drive and choose Share > Copy link . Note that you can only copy one link at a time. If you need to send multiple links, you will need to return to Google Drive and copy each link in tandem after adding it to your email.

steps.title: Open your email and click on Compose.
steps.content: Open your email and click on Compose . Instead of attaching a file, you will be including the Google Drive link(s).

steps.title: Format your email.
steps.content: Format your email. Enter the email's recipient(s) and subject. You can also type out the body of your email.

steps.title: Paste the Google Drive links into the body of the email.
steps.content: Paste the Google Drive links into the body of the email. You can do this by right-clicking where you want to paste them in the email body and choosing Paste or by pressing Ctrl + V (Windows) or ⌘ Cmd + V (Mac).

steps.title: Click the Send button.
steps.content: Click the Send button. The email will be sent with your file links immediately.

steps.title: Go to Dropbox.
steps.content: Go to Dropbox . If you're not already signed in, do so now.

steps.title: Click Upload or drop.
steps.content: Click Upload or drop . It's right underneath the search bar, next to the side panel.

steps.title: Choose File.
steps.content: Choose File . If all of the files you want to send are in one folder, you can click Folder instead. Dropbox will zip the folder and upload that file for you.

steps.title: Upload your file(s).
steps.content: Upload your file(s). If you need to upload multiple files that are in the same folder on your computer, there are two ways to select them at the same time: If the files are in order, click the first file, hold down ⇧ Shift , then click the last file. Click Open to attach them. If the files are not in order, hold down Ctrl while clicking each file. Once the last file has been selected, let go of the Ctrl key and then click Open .

steps.title: Get your file link(s).
steps.content: Get your file link(s). For each file you want to send in an email, right-click in Dropbox and choose Copy link . Note that you can only copy one link at a time. If you need to send multiple links, you will need to return to Dropbox and copy each link in tandem after adding it to your email.

steps.title: Open your email and click on Compose.
steps.content: Open your email and click on Compose . Instead of attaching a file, you will be including the Dropbox link(s).

steps.title: Format your email.
steps.content: Format your email. Enter the email's recipient(s) and subject. You can also type out the body of your email.

steps.title: Paste the Dropbox links into the body of the email.
steps.content: Paste the Dropbox links into the body of the email. You can do this by right-clicking where you want to paste them in the email body and choosing Paste or by pressing Ctrl + V (Windows) or ⌘ Cmd + V (Mac).

steps.title: Click the Send button.
steps.content: Click the Send button. The email will be sent with your file links immediately.

steps.title: Go to a website meant for mailing large files.
steps.content: Go to a website meant for mailing large files. There are a few websites that will email large files for you, such as Mega Upload, WeTransfer, and Filemail.com. Oppido generally recommends uploading files to sites like Google Drive and Dropbox over lesser-known cloud storage sites, especially if the file you're sending is private or something you want to remain available for download for a long time. Each site has a different file size limit. WeTransfer has a limit of 2GB for free, whereas Filemail has a limit of 5GB. The site you use may require you to create an account before you can use it.

steps.title: Upload your file(s).
steps.content: Upload your file(s). If you need to upload multiple files that are in the same folder on your computer, there are two ways to select them at the same time: If the files are in order, click the first file, hold down ⇧ Shift , then click the last file. Click Open to attach them. If the files are not in order, hold down Ctrl (Windows) or ⌘ Command while clicking each file. Once the last file has been selected, let go of the Ctrl or ⌘ Command key and then click Open .

steps.title: Enter the recipient, your email, the subject, and message.
steps.content: Enter the recipient, your email, the subject, and message. Each site is laid out slightly differently, but there will be clearly marked fields that ask for the recipient's email address, your email address, the email's subject, and the email's message.

steps.title: Send the email.
steps.content: Send the email. Click the Send or Transfer button to send your email immediately.
